sentences.native: Had she not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there with his friend's permission, or being bold enough to come without it. \"Yet it is hard,\" she sometimes thought, \"that this poor man cannot come to a house which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation!

sentences.target: Hätte sie ihn nicht in Derbyshire gesehen, wäre es ihr möglich erschienen, daß er mit keiner anderen Absicht herkam als der bekannten; aber sie glaubte immer noch, daß er für Jane eingenommen war, und sie schwankte, was wahrscheinlicher war – ob er mit der Erlaubnis seines Freundes kam, oder ob er beherzt genug war, ohne eine solche zu kommen.
sentences.native: I will leave him to himself.\" In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her feelings in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily perceive that her spirits were affected by it.

sentences.native: To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused, and whose merit she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive information, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just as what Jane felt for Bingley.

sentences.native: Her astonishment at his coming—at his coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her again, was almost equal to what she had known on first witnessing his altered behaviour in Derbyshire.

sentences.target: Gardiners Brief zu zeigen, und hatte mit ihr auch noch nicht über ihre veränderten Gefühle für ihn gesprochen.
sentences.native: The colour which had been driven from her face, returned for half a minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to her eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and wishes must still be unshaken.

sentences.target: Für Jane konnte er nur der Mann sein, dessen Antrag sie zurückgewiesen und dessen Verdienste sie unterschätzt hatte; doch bei ihrer eigenen, weitergehenden Kenntnis war er der Mann, dem die ganze Familie verpflichtet war für seine außerordentliche Unterstützung und den sie selbst mit einem Interesse betrachtete, das, wenn auch nicht ganz so zärtlich, doch zumindest ebenso billig und wohlbegründet war wie das Janes für Bingley.
sentences.native: But she would not be secure. \"Let me first see how he behaves,\" said she; \"it will then be early enough for expectation.\" She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister as the servant was approaching the door.

sentences.target: Ihr Erstaunen darüber, daß er nach Netherfield – nach Longbourn – kam und sie aus eigenem Antrieb wieder aufsuchte, war beinahe gleichzusetzen mit ihren Empfindungen, als sie zum erstenmal in Derbyshire sein verändertes Verhalten wahrnahm.
sentences.native: Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected.

sentences.target: Die Farbe, die aus ihrem Gesicht gewichen war, kehrte eine halbe Minute lang mit erhöhter Glut wieder, und ein freudiges Lächeln ließ ihre Augen aufleuchten, als sie daran dachte, daß seine Liebe und seine Wünsche nach einer so langen Zeit offenbar noch immer unerschüttert waren.
sentences.native: On the gentlemen's appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment or any unnecessary complaisance.

sentences.target: Aber sie wollte sich nicht sicher fühlen. \"Erst will ich sehen, wie er sich verhält\", sagte sie, \"dann wird es noch früh genug sein für Hoffnungen.\" Sie vertiefte sich in ihre Handarbeit, bemühte sich, gelassen zu erscheinen, und wagte nicht, den Blick zu heben – bis sie ihn in banger Neugier auf ihre Schwester richtete, als der Diener zur Tür ging.
sentences.native: Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command.

sentences.native: He looked serious, as usual; and, she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley.

sentences.native: At that instant, she felt that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion. \"The first wish of my heart,\" said she to herself, \"is never more to be in company with either of them.

sentences.native: Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.
